an5.166:4.1: There Venerable Sāriputta addressed the mendicants: … “Reverends, take a mendicant who is accomplished in ethics, samādhi, and wisdom. They might enter into and emerge from the cessation of perception and feeling.
an5.166:4.3: If they don’t reach enlightenment in this very life, then, surpassing the company of gods that consume solid food, they’re reborn in a certain group of mind-made gods. There they might enter into and emerge from the cessation of perception and feeling.
an5.166:5.1: When he said this, Venerable Udāyin said to him:
an5.166:5.2: “This is not possible, Reverend Sāriputta, it cannot happen!”
an5.166:6.1: But for a second … and a third time Sāriputta repeated his statement.
an5.166:7.1: And for a third time, Udāyī said to him:
an5.166:7.2: “This is not possible, Reverend Sāriputta, it cannot happen!”
an5.166:8.2: “Venerable Udāyī disagrees with me three times, and not one mendicant agrees with me.
an5.166:8.3: Why don’t I go to see the Buddha?”
an5.166:8.4: Then Sāriputta went up to the Buddha,
an5.166:8.5: bowed, sat down to one side,
an5.166:8.7: “Reverends, take a mendicant who is accomplished in ethics, samādhi, and wisdom. They might enter into and emerge from the cessation of perception and feeling.
an5.166:8.9: If they don’t reach enlightenment in this very life, they’re reborn in the company of a certain group of mind-made gods, who surpass the gods that consume solid food. There they might enter into and emerge from the cessation of perception and feeling.
an5.166:9.1: When he said this, Udāyin said to him:
an5.166:9.2: If they don’t reach enlightenment in this very life, they’re reborn in the company of a certain group of mind-made gods, who surpass the gods that consume solid food. There they might enter into and emerge from the cessation of perception and feeling.
an5.166:10.1: But for a second … and a third time Sāriputta repeated his statement.
an5.166:11.1: And for a third time, Udāyī said to him:
an5.166:11.2: “This is not possible, Reverend Sāriputta, it cannot happen!”
an5.166:12.2: “Even in front of the Buddha Venerable Udāyī disagrees with me three times, and not one mendicant agrees with me.
an5.166:13.1: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Udāyī:
an5.166:13.3: “Those gods, sir, who are formless, made of perception.”
an5.166:13.4: “Udāyī, what’s an incompetent fool like you got to say?
an5.166:13.5: How on earth could you imagine you’ve got something worth saying!”
an5.166:14.1: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Ānanda:
an5.166:14.2: “Ānanda! There’s a senior mendicant being harassed, and you just watch it happening.
an5.166:14.3: Don’t you have any compassion for a senior mendicant who is being harassed?”
an5.166:15.1: Then the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
an5.166:15.2: “Mendicants, take a mendicant who is accomplished in ethics, samādhi, and wisdom. They might enter into and emerge from the cessation of perception and feeling.
an5.166:15.4: If they don’t reach enlightenment in this very life, they’re reborn in the company of a certain group of mind-made gods, who surpass the gods that consume solid food. There they might enter into and emerge from the cessation of perception and feeling.
an5.166:15.6: This is what the Buddha said.
an5.166:15.7: When he had spoken, the Holy One got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.
an5.166:16.1: Then, not long after the Buddha had left, Venerable Ānanda went to Venerable Upavāṇa
an5.166:16.3: “Reverend Upavāṇa, they’ve been harassing other senior mendicants,
an5.166:16.5: I wouldn’t be surprised if the Buddha says something about this when he comes out of solitude later this afternoon. He might even call upon Venerable Upavāṇa himself.
an5.166:16.6: And right now I feel timid.”
an5.166:16.7: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of solitude and went to the assembly hall,
an5.166:16.8: where he sat on the indicated seat,
an5.166:17.1: “Upavāṇa, how many qualities should a senior mendicant have to be liked and approved by their spiritual companions, respected and admired?”
an5.166:17.2: “Sir, a senior mendicant with five qualities is liked and approved by their spiritual companions, respected and admired.
an5.166:17.4: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the code of conduct, and has appropriate behavior and means of collecting alms. Seeing danger in the slightest flaw, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
an5.166:17.5: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s totally full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reciting them, mentally scrutinizing them, and understanding them with right view.
an5.166:17.6: They’re a good speaker, with a polished, clear, and articulate voice that expresses the meaning.
an5.166:17.7: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in the present life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.
an5.166:17.8: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having achieved it with their own insight due to the end of defilements.
an5.166:17.9: A senior mendicant with these five qualities is liked and approved by their spiritual companions, respected and admired.”
an5.166:18.2: A senior mendicant with these five qualities is liked and approved by their spiritual companions, respected and admired.
an5.166:18.3: If these five qualities are not found in a senior mendicant, why would their spiritual companions honor, respect, revere, or worship them? Because of their broken teeth, grey hair, and wrinkled skin?
an5.166:18.4: But since these five qualities are found in a senior mendicant, their spiritual companions honor, respect, revere, or worship them.”
